gold_sents: On March 25, 2015, the plaintiffs filed a consumer class action on behalf of consumers nationwide who had been the subject of misleading and inaccurate background reports sold by the defendant, RealPage, Inc. to landlords.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), alleging that the defendant, RealPage, Inc., adopted and maintained a policy and practice of failing to timely update the criminal record information it maintained so as to eliminate records of cases that have been expunged, thus not accurately reflecting the final disposition of these cases.[SENTMARKER]Moreover, the plaintiffs alleged that the defendant systematically violated FCRA by failing to provide complete and accurate disclosures of all information the defendant maintains about consumers to these consumers upon request.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled, and the defendant agreed to provide consumers additional information about federal agencies responsible for enforcing FCRA, refrain from including expunged criminal records in tenant screening reports, and disclose the names of vendors who retrieved criminal record information to consumers, plus damages.[SENTMARKER]The settlement term ended in 2020, and the case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2020, the Nashville Community Bail Fund filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that a local rule which required it to agree to garnishment of judgment fees from bail bonds before it could post bail for indigent arrestees violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the Constitution and threatened its ability to operate as a non-profit.[SENTMARKER]The District Judge granted a preliminary injunction in March 2020 enjoining the County Criminal Court Clerk from garnishing fees from bonds posted by the Bail Fund.[SENTMARKER]In December 2020, the District Judge approved a consent decree where the Bail Fund and the County Government agreed to make the injunction permanent.[SENTMARKER]The matter is ongoing as the parties are litigating over who should pay attorneys fees and how much.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: Nashville Community Bail Fund (NCBF) brought this action against the Metropolitan Government of Nashville and the Criminal Court Clerk in the Middle District Court of Tennessee.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the court violated the Eighth Amendment by failing to enforce Rule 10(B) of the Constitution, which requires bail bonds to be posted as a supersedeas to a judgment for the payment of a fine.[SENTMARKER]The court granted NCBF a preliminary injunction, enjoining the criminal court clerk from enforcing the rule during the pendency of this action.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the injunction should become a permanent injunction, and the court retained jurisdiction for the purpose of enforcing the terms of the consent decree.

gold_sents: In May of 2016 two indigent people brought a suit against the City of El Paso in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Texas for jailing them for failure to pay fines, despite their inability to do so.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs brought this action under 42 U.S.C. 1983, and allege that the Defendants violated their Due Process and Equal Protection rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs request declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]They want to enjoin the Defendants from enforcing their current debt collection program, which jails people who can't pay a certain portion of their fines for traffic and misdemeanor offenses.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that Defendants adopted their debt collection program to generate revenue for they city, and the individual plaintiffs were not informed that they could assert their indigence.[SENTMARKER]Rather, the Plaintiffs were simply told they had to pay or go to jail.[SENTMARKER]On January 12th, 2017 Judge David Guaderrama granted the Defendant's motion to dismiss in part.[SENTMARKER]Judge Guaderrama dismissed the Due Process claims, but did not reach the Equal Protection claims.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint in January 2017, and after the Court denied two motions to dismiss filed by defendants over the course of 2017, the parties stipulated to dismissal of the action pursuant to a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In the settlement agreement, defendants agreed to maintain certain administrative practices for three years.[SENTMARKER]Among other things, these practices related to notice to defendants, policies and procedures for: payment plans; notice to defendants of court hearings and schedules; and indigency hearings and warrants issued for non-payment.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In January 2017, a class action lawsuit was filed against the City ofEl Paso for violating the Due Process and Equal Protection rights of people who were too poor to pay a significant portion of their debt upfront under the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution and the Civil Rights Act of 1871.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the city's debt collection policies and practices for Class C misdemeanor fines in connection with traffic tickets were unconstitutional and violated the due process and equal protection rights of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The district court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the parties reached a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required the defendants to stop enforcing these unconstitutional policies, practices, and procedures against the same class of indigent Municipal Debtors, and in the same manner, as Defendant did against plaintiffs.

gold_sents: On December 2, 2020, the U.S. Department of Justice filed a complaint against the National Railroad Passenger Corporation (“Amtrak”) for allegedly violating the Americans with Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 12131-12165, by failing to make its intercity rail stations accessible to individuals with disabilities by July 26, 2020, as required by the Act.[SENTMARKER]The case was never properly docketed or assigned to a judge, however, because the government announced its settlement with Amtrak on the same day.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement required Amtrak to design at least 135 accessible stations, complete construction at 90 stations, and be in the process of constructing at least 45 stations within 10 years of the settlement date.[SENTMARKER]The agreement also required Amtrak to train staff on ADA compliance, establish a monitor-approved process for managing ADA complaints, and create a settlement fund to compensate individuals who were harmed by Amtrak’s most inaccessible stations.[SENTMARKER]The settlement was monitored by the Federal Railroad Administration and the Department of Justice.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.

gold_sents: Financial advisors who sued their employer, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., for race and gender discrimination in compensation did not state a plausible claim, so their complaint was dismissed pursuant to Title VII Section 703(h), which allows employers to compensate employees differently on the basis of seniority, merit, or quality or quantity of production.[SENTMARKER]The differences in compensation are only unlawful when they result from an intention to discriminate because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin.

gold_sents: In 2012, the Catholic Archbishop of Washington and several affiliated Catholic organizations filed a lawsuit in the District of DC against the Federal Government under the Religious Freedom Restoration Act, the Administrative Procedure Act, and the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs contended that this mandatory contraception coverage violated their sincerely held religious beliefs, and seek to enjoin their enforcement.[SENTMARKER]This case was dismissed for lack of ripeness on January 25, 2013, and refiled on September 20, 2013.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others, and is known as Zubik v. gold_sents: In 2012, evangelical Christian business owners filed a RFRA challenge to rules adopted pursuant to the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, arguing that the rules infringed on their religious freedom by requiring them to provide coverage for emergency contraception through their group health insurance plan.[SENTMARKER]In November 2012, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding that the contraception mandate did not substantially burden the plaintiffs' religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]The 10th Circuit granted expedited en banc review, and oral arguments occurred on May 23.[SENTMARKER]On June 27, 2013, the 10th Circuit reversed the District Court's injunction denial and sent the case back to the District Court, with instructions to consider two prongs of the injunction inquiry and to rule on the plaintiffs' injunction motion.[SENTMARKER]The next day, the District Court granted the plaintiffs' emergency motion for a temporary injunction pending the full injunction hearing.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted cert., and on June 30, 2014, affirmed the 10th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Court said other ways were open to the government to reach its asserted interest of ensuring the availability of contraception coverage.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 19, 2010, two Oklahoma corporations and their families filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma, alleging that regulations implementing the 2010 Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act force them to violate their sincerely held religious beliefs.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction pending resolution of the appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit denied the motion for an injunction, and the Supreme Court reversed the lower court's decision.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court held that the plaintiffs' challenge to the contraceptive coverage requirement fails on the merits.

gold_sents: In 2013, a group of religious-based universities filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court of the Western District of Oklahoma under the First Amendment, Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause, Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA) and the Administrative Procedure Act against federal government.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged the Affordable Care Act's requirement that employee and student health plans provide coverage of contraception violated their religious foundings.[SENTMARKER]On November 6, 2015, the Supreme Court granted certiorari on the question of whether the accommodation to the contraceptive services mandate as applied to religious nonprofits violates the RFRA.[SENTMARKER]This case was consolidated with six others.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court issued a per curiam order remanding all seven cases to their respective courts of appeals, and ordered that the parties be given time to come to agreement on ensuring contraceptive access without burdening religious freedom.[SENTMARKER]Following revised HHS policies, the District Court permanently enjoined the defendants from forcing religious organizations to provide contraceptive care.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2010, a group of Oklahoma college and university presidents filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Oklahoma against the Departments of Health and Human Services and the Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the government violated the Religious Freedom Restoration Act (RFRA), the Free Exercise, Establishment and Free Speech Clauses of the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment by requiring them to provide free coverage of contraceptive services, including so-called emergency contraceptives that cause early abortions.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that non-objecting employers could provide contraceptive coverage under their group health plans, but the court was not confronted with the question of whether those beliefs were substantially burdened.[SENTMARKER]On July 23, 2015, the plaintiffs filed petitions for certiorari to the Supreme Court.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court declined to hear the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is now consolidated.

After the Trump Administration took office, the parties settled and dismissed the case.

gold_sents: The lawsuit was based on fair housing testing that DOJ had conducted between July 2008 and January 2009, in which rental agents made a series of racialized remarks, steering white testers away from certain locations, and implying that black applicants were more likely to fail criminal background checks.[SENTMARKER]On July 21, 2009, the United States Department of Justice filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama under the Fair Housing Act, 42 U.S.C. §3601, against operators of the Rolling Oaks Apartments, seeking injunctive and monetary relief for race discrimination.[SENTMARKER]After the court (Judge Mark Fuller) denied cross-motions for summary judgment, the matter settled.[SENTMARKER]In February 2011, the Court entered a four-year consent decree enjoining the Defendants from discriminating on the basis of race in the operation of the Rolling Oaks Apartments and ordering  $15,500 in civil penalties.

gold_sents: The United States Department of Justice filed a lawsuit under the Fair Housing and Equal Credit Opportunity Acts against PrimeLending, claiming that the defendant displayed a pattern or practice of discrimination in lending on the basis of race against African-American borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a consent order in which Primelending agreed to refrain from practicing race based discrimination, submit to a monitoring and reporting program, provide borrowers with a general notice of nondiscrimination, provide equal credit opportunity training to its employees, provide a total of $2 million to be distributed among those aggrieved,  allocate any unclaimed portion of the $2 million to organizations that provide general financial education to African-American borrowers, and maintain a complaint resolution program to resolve discrimination claims.

Junell) approved a consent order in which the bank agreed to implement a variety of practices to address these alleged violations and to pay damages to aggrieved borrowers.[SENTMARKER]The consent order remained in effect until early 2017.[SENTMARKER]Since there has been no substantive docket activity after 2014, the case is presumably closed.

gold_sents: On September 26, 2013, the United States of America filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Wisconsin against Southport Bank, under the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff, represented by the Civil Rights Division of the Department of Justice, sought a declaratory judgment, injunctive relief, compensatory damages to all of the victims of the defendant's discriminatory policies, and a civil penalty, alleging that the defendant discriminated against African American and Hispanic borrowers because of race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]On October 11, 2013, the District Court (Judge Joseph Peter Stadtmueller) entered a consent order between the parties.[SENTMARKER]The defendant did not admit to any pattern or practice of discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The order enjoined the defendant from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or national origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the Fair Housing Act or any credit transaction in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act.  Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 26, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Wisconsin entered a final judgment against Southport Bank of Kenosha, Wisconsin for violating the Fair Housing Act and the Equal Credit Opportunity Act by discriminating against African-American and Hispanic borrowers in its residential mortgage lending.[SENTMARKER]The final judgment, which was entered on October 11, 2013, is subject to review and approval by the United States Department of Justice.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered Southport to pay $687,000 in monetary damages to affected persons.[SENTMARKER]The judgment also enjoined Southport from engaging in any act or practice that discriminates on the basis of race or ethnic origin in any aspect of a residential real estate-related transaction in violation of the FHA or the ECOA.[SENTMARKER]Southport was also ordered to pay a civil penalty in an amount authorized by 42 U.s.C.  3614(d)(1)(C) in order to vindicate the public interest.

gold_sents: Following an investigation by the United States Department of Justice, the U.S. filed this lawsuit against the State of Connecticut, its Department of Mental Retardation, and the Director of Southbury Training School (Southbury) on July 25, 1986, alleging that living conditions at Southbury placed residents in grave danger of bodily harm and death.[SENTMARKER]On the same day, the parties also entered into a consent decree that required Southbury to provide better programming, disciplinary procedures, medical care, recordkeeping, and increase staffing.[SENTMARKER]After some problems with compliance and placing the state in contempt, the Court assigned a special master to monitor Southbury.[SENTMARKER]After making significant progress, on March 25, 2006, the court ended judicial oversight, but retained jurisdiction over the consent decree and remedial plan.[SENTMARKER]On November 2, 2009, the Court granted a joint motion to dismiss the case because the parties agreed that the consent decree and remedial plan were fully implemented.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 25, 2011, a class action lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Indiana against the city of Indianapolis, the State of Indiana, and the United States Department of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the constitutionality of the recently enacted Senate Enrolled Act 590 (SEA 590), which was adopted by the Indiana General Assembly and originally scheduled to take effect on July 1, 2011.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the plaintiffs challenged Section 18 of the Act, which allows state and local law enforcement officers to make a warrantless arrest of a person if the officer has a removal order issued by an immigration court, a detainer or notice of action issued by USCIS, or probable cause to believe that the person has been indicted for or convicted of at least one aggravated felony.[SENTMARKER]The Act also prohibits the use of consular identification cards for purposes of the I-9 Employment Eligibility Form.[SENTMARKER]On June 24, 2011, the court entered a preliminary injunction in favor of the plaintiffs enjoining the defendants from enforcing Section 18 and Section 20 until further order.[SENTMARKER]On April 20, 2012, the court granted summary judgment against the defendants.

gold_sents: Sixteen states filed this lawsuit against the federal government on September 6, 2017 in response to the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) memorandum issued on Sept.[SENTMARKER]5 ending Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA).[SENTMARKER]The states sought to enjoin the federal government from carrying out portions of the DHS memorandum and from using information about DACA grantees gathered in their applications to enforce immigration policy.[SENTMARKER]While the district court granted in part the government’s motion to dismiss, the plaintiffs obtained a preliminary injunction.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the Supreme Court held that DHS's decision to rescind DACA was subject to judicial review under the APA and that the rescission was unlawful.[SENTMARKER]Shortly thereafter, the Acting DHS Secretary issued a memorandum suspending DACA while DHS reviewed it.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs filed an amended complaint alleging that the Acting Secretary lacked the authority to issue the memorandum because he had not been lawfully appointed to his position.[SENTMARKER]The district court agreed.[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court vacated the memorandum and ordered DHS to resume processing DACA applications.[SENTMARKER]This case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2012, the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) created the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, which was then rescinded in 2017 by the acting secretary of DHS.[SENTMARKER]The district courts granted a preliminary nationwide injunction, while the third vacated the rescission.[SENTMARKER]On June 18, 2020, the U.S. Supreme Court held that the acting Secretary's decision to rescind DACA was arbitrary and capricious under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).

gold_sents: In 2018, several states filed a complaint against the Department of Justice in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the immigration-related conditions being placed on funding disbursed by the Department of Justice violated the Separation of Powers, the APA and the Tenth Amendment Anti-Commandeering.[SENTMARKER]In 2018, a judge granted partial summary judgment in favor of the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]In 2019, the defendants appealed this judgment.[SENTMARKER]And later, the plaintiffs made a motion for summary judgment on the 2018 immigration-related conditions.[SENTMARKER]In February 2020, a Second Circuit panel reversed the district court's order granting partial summary judgment, vacated the mandate and injunction, and remanded the case to the district court, concluding that the Attorney General was statutorily authorized to impose the challenged conditions and that the imposition of these conditions was not arbitrary and capricious.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment is currently pending before the district court.

gold_sents: On February 1, 2008, national, state and local chambers of commerce and other nonprofit organizations advocating for their members' business interests filed a lawsuit against the State of Oklahoma, claiming that Sections 7 and 9 of the Oklahoma Taxpayer and Citizen Protection Act, which impose tax penalties on businesses that don't check the work eligibility of all of their employees in a federal database and allow discharged employees to bring discrimination suits against their employers for employing unauthorized workers, were preempted by the federal Immigration Reform and Control Act.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted the plaintiffs a preliminary injunction on June 4, 2008, and on appeal to the Tenth Circuit the injunction was upheld except for as to the verification requirement.[SENTMARKER]On remand to the District Court, the case was stayed pending the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: On July 16, 2019, the East Bay Sanctuary Covenant, Al Otro Lado, Innovation Law Lab, and the Central American Resource Center in Los Angeles brought this suit against the U.S. Attorney General and  Secretary of Homeland Security.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs challenged the federal immigration rule restricting eligibility for asylum for noncitizens who transited through another country prior to reaching the southern U.S. border.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed the rule violated the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA).[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs successfully sought a preliminary nationwide injunction.[SENTMARKER]However, defendants appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit and the nationwide scope of the injunction was stayed.[SENTMARKER]Then the District Court restored the nationwide scope of the injunction on September 9, 2019, but the government again appealed and the U.S. Supreme Court granted a stay pending disposition of the appeal in the 9th Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The District Court issued a separate preliminary injunction against another rule issued by the Department of Homeland Security in the closing days of the Trump Administration which was substantially similar to the one already enjoined.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit upheld the original injunction in April, 2021.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing but is likely to terminate soon given the change in presidential administrations.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On July 16, 2019, the District Court for the District of California granted a preliminary injunction against the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) in a case that challenged the DHS's use of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) to bar noncitizens who transit through another country prior to reaching the southern border.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that the rule was likely unlawful for at least three reasons, including that it violated the procedural steps of the APA and the Refugee Act of 1980 (Refugee Act), and that the DHS had not complied with the requirements of the INA.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed that order to the Ninth Circuit and moved for a stay pending appeal.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court of the United States stayed the district court's July 24, 2019 preliminary injunction and September 9, 2019 order restoring the nationwide scope of the injunction.

gold_sents: On August 16, 2019, several health care providers and nonprofit organizations serving immigrant communities filed this suit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs challenged the Department of Homeland Security's Final Public Charge Rule (the Rule), which added non-cash benefits to the factors considered in determining whether a person applying for legal permanent residence is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Government violated the Administrative Procedure Act by exceeding its statutory authority, claimed that the Rule was "arbitrary and capricious," and asserted that the Rule violated the Equal Protection Clause of the Fifth Amendment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2019, a district court judge denied the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction enjoining the government from implementing the Rule, but issued an order for preliminary injunction in a related case that would enjoin the implementation of the rule in California, Oregon, the District of Columbia, Maine, and Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]This preliminary injunction was stayed by the Ninth Circuit in December 2019.[SENTMARKER]It was affirmed a year later in December 2020, but the order was stayed pending petitions to the Supreme Court in the Second, Seventh, and Ninth Circuits.[SENTMARKER]The Rule was abandoned by DHS on March 9, 2021.[SENTMARKER]As of April 15, 2021, the case is ongoing.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On August 14, 2019, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) published a final rule entitled 22 "Inadmissibility on Public Charge Grounds" (the "Rule") which, among other things, required the government to consider the past or possible future receipt of non-cash or supplemental assistance in determining whether an alien is likely to become a public charge.[SENTMARKER]On December 10, 2019, the counties of San Francisco, Santa Clara County, the States of California, Oregon, or Maine, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, or the District of Columbia filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Rule was arbitrary and capricious and was motivated by animus toward non-white immigrants.[SENTMARKER]The district court issued a preliminary injunction enjoining 23 defendants from applying the Rule to any person residing in the City and County of San Fransisco, San Jose, or Santa Clara, County.[SENTMARKER]The court found that the harm alleged by 2 plaintiffs was sufficient to create standing.[SENTMARKER]The case was ultimately dismissed by the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: On December 19, 2018 two US Airmen under pseudonym and OutServe-SLDN, a network of LGBTQ military service-people, filed suit against the U.S. Department of Defense, James Mattis, and Heather Wilson in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs argued that the U.S had violated equal protection under the fifth amendment and the Administrative Procedure Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs represented by Winston and Strawn LLP, LAMBDA Legal Defense and Education Fund, and Outserve-SLDN (now known as the Modern Military Association of America) sought declaratory and injunctive relief allowing HIV positive service members to continue to serve and damages.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiffs allege that they were discharged from their duties in the Air Force due to their HIV status.[SENTMARKER]The case was assigned to Judge Leonie M. gold_sents: In 2020, two immigration detainees in the Batavia Federal Detention Facility in Batavia, NY, filed this class action in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that they and others similarly situated had been improperly denied bond, that non-bond alternatives to detention had not been properly considered by their immigration judges, that such considerations were required by the Immigration and Nationality Act, and that the policy of placing the burden of proof on the Plaintiffs to show they posed no flight risk violated their Fifth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]The court granted relief for pre-hearing detainees, agreeing that they pled sufficient facts to state a Due Process Claim that the government is required to bear the burden of proof at bond hearings for individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. §1226(a).[SENTMARKER]It denied Plaintiffs' request to certify the putative post-hearing class.[SENTMARKER]Both parties appealed; the case is ongoing.

gold_sents: Two detainees in Shelby County Jail in Tennessee filed this petition for a writ of habeas corpus.[SENTMARKER]They claimed that failure to take sufficient COVID-19 precautions violated the Fourteenth Amendment, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and they sought release.[SENTMARKER]The court appointed an "Independent Inspector" to assess conditions at the jail and, based on his report, denied preliminary relief.[SENTMARKER]The court also denied defendants' motion to dismiss, and a trial is scheduled for May 2021.[SENTMARKER]An Independent Inspector was tasked with inspecting the jail to evaluate the conditions.[SENTMARKER]While praising defendants' professionalism, he wrote that several adjustments needed to be made in order for the jail to be a safe place for detainees.[SENTMARKER]After attending mediation and filing a joint motion for preliminary approval of class action settlement, the court preliminarily granted the consent decree requiring monthly reports on the status of COVID-19 in the Jail and unannounced, periodic inspections by the Inspector.[SENTMARKER]A final approval hearing is scheduled for March 5, 2021.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 14, 2013, the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California ruled that the National Security Letter (NSL) statute was facially unconstitutional under the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The NSL statute was amended by the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015, Pub L. 114-23, 129 Stat.[SENTMARKER]The court held that the NSL law, as amended, was constitutional and enjoined the government from issuing 5 NSLs under 2709 or enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 30, 2004, a class action was brought on behalf of qualified welfare beneficiaries who claimed to have been deprived of federally sponsored cash assistance, food stamp and Medicaid benefits in violation of federal and state law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion to certify as a class and granted their motion for preliminary injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the district court's holding that the state did not have non-delegable duty to administer decentralized food stamp, Medicaid, or cash assistance programs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted plaintiffs' request for a permanent injunction requiring the defendants to provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applicants when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when they are denied and withdrawn; and (iii) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing Forms W145HH and M3 in accord with 42 U.S.C.  1396 et seq., and New York Social Services Law  133.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which granted the defendants' appeal on January 31, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties are awaiting the outcome of the appeal.

(DAI) filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York against the New York State Department of Health and the Governor of the State, alleging that the State was violating the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to provide services to its residents with mental illness.[SENTMARKER]DAI sought declaratory and injunctive relief requiring the State to ensure that its constituents at the 28 adult homes receive services in the most integrated setting appropriate to their needs.[SENTMARKER]On March 1, 2010, the District Court granted DAI's motion for partial summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]On April 6, 2012, the Second Circuit vacated the district court's remedial order and dismissed the action for lack of jurisdiction.[SENTMARKER]On November 18, 2014, DAI and the State entered into a settlement agreement.

gold_sents: Plaintiffs are lesbian couples who filed suit on November 3, 2004 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma, against the United States and the State of Oklahoma, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief that the federal Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and Article 2 § 35 of the Oklahoma Constitution (the "Oklahoma Amendment") violate the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that DOMA and the Oklahoma Amendment violates the Due Process, Equal Protection, Full Faith and Credit, and Privileges and Immunities Clauses of the U.S. Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The court found for the plaintiffs, holding on Jan.[SENTMARKER]14, 2014 that the ban on same-sex marriage violated the Equal Protection Clause.[SENTMARKER]The Tenth Circuit found for the plaintiffs on July 18, 2014, and after the Supreme Court denied a petition for a writ of certiorari (on October 6, 2014), the Court lifted the stay on its original mandate and enjoined the Defendant from enforcing the Oklahoma Amendment and denying same-sex couples marriage licenses.[SENTMARKER]The Court awarded $309,485.27 in attorney's fees to the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 3, 2004, two lesbian couples filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Oklahoma seeking declaratory relief that the Defense of Marriage Act (DOMA) and the Oklahoma Amendment (the Oklahoma Amendment) violated the Fourteenth Amendment due process and equal protection clauses of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]On July 8, 2010, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court ruled 4-3 that the state's ban on same-sex marriage is unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On October 6, 2014, the United States Supreme Court denied the petition, and the Tenth Circuit lifted the stay of its mandate.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution protects all persons, including prisoners, from invidious discrimination based on race.[SENTMARKER]On September 13, 2013, a prisoner in the custody of the Arizona Department of 7 Corrections filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that racially segregated housing in the Tucson Prison Complex violated his rights under the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiff's motion for summary judgment on December 22, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The court also granted his motion for a permanent injunction and for attorney's fees and costs.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: January 17, 2018 | Southern District of Florida ORG ||| Florida Department of Corrections ORG||||||| Dade Correctional Institution ORG ORG<n>Disability Rights Florida (DRF), an organization empowered by Federal law to protect the rights of mentally ill individuals in Florida, filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District Of Florida on January 17, 2018.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act by failing to provide adequate mental health care to inmates housed in Dade's inpatient mental health unit.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the parties reached a settlement in full in January 2018.
